review.title: A multiple instance learning approach for sequence data with across bag dependencies
review.abstract: In Multiple Instance Learning (MIL) problem for sequence data, the learning data consist of a set of bags where each bag contains a set of instances/sequences. In many real world applications such as bioinformatics, web mining, and text mining, comparing a random couple of sequences makes no sense. In fact, each instance of each bag may have structural and/or temporal relation with other instances in other bags. Thus, the classification task should take into account the relation between semantically related instances across bags. In this paper, we present two novel MIL approaches for sequence data classification: (1) ABClass and (2) ABSim. In ABClass, each sequence is represented by one vector of attributes. For each sequence of the unknown bag, a discriminative classifier is applied in order to compute a partial classification result. Then, an aggregation method is applied to these partial results in order to generate the final result. In ABSim, we use a similarity measure between each sequence of the unknown bag and the corresponding sequences in the learning bags. An unknown bag is labeled with the bag that presents more similar sequences. We applied both approaches to the problem of bacterial Ionizing Radiation Resistance (IRR) prediction. We evaluated and discussed the proposed approaches on well known Ionizing Radiation Resistance Bacteria (IRRB) and Ionizing Radiation Sensitive Bacteria (IRSB) represented by primary structure of basal DNA repair proteins. The experimental results show that both ABClass and ABSim approaches are efficient.
histories: Submitted to Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery Journal
review.COMMENTS: Submitted to Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery Journal

metadata.title: A multiple instance learning approach for sequence data with across bag dependencies

sections.text: Keywords Multiple instance learning; classification of sequence data; across bag dependencies; prediction; bacterial ionizing radiation resistance

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: In fact, it is that we are able to assert ourselves, that we are able, that we are able to change the world in which we find ourselves.

sections.heading: 2. BACKGROUND
sections.text: In this section, we present the background information on MIL in sequence data. First, we describe the terminology and problem formulation. Then, we present a simple use case that serves as a running example in this essay.

sections.heading: 2.1 Problem formulation
sections.text: A sequence is an ordered list of events. An event can be represented as a symbolic value, a numerical value, a vector of values, or a complex data type. [19] There are many types of sequences, including symbolic sequences, simple time series, and multivariate time series. In our work, we are interested in symbolic sequences, since protein sequences are described by symbols (amino acids). We designate an alphabet defined as a finite set of characters or symbols. A symbolic sequence is defined as an ordered list of symbols. A sequence s with the length P is written as: s = s1, s2,..., sP, where sl-A value is a symbol at position L. Let DB be a learning database that defines a set of n labeled pockets DB = {(Bi, Yi), i = 2, n}, where the sequence is a sequence of Bi.

sections.heading: 2.2 Running example
sections.text: To illustrate our proposed approaches, we rely on the following ongoing example. Let Σ = {A, B,.., Z} be a learning database containing four bags. Let DB = {(B1, + 1), (B2, + 1), (B3, − 1), (B4, − 1) be a learning database containing four bags. Positive bags consist of B1 and B2 and negative bags consist of B3 and B4.B1 = {B11 = ABMSCDB12 = EFNOGH (1) B2 = {B21 = EABZQCDB22 = CCGHDDEF (2) B3 = {B31 = CDXYZB32 = GHWXY (3) B4 = {B41 = ABIJYZB42 = EFY RTAB (4) We note that B11, B21, B31 and B41 are related through a cross-border bag relationship. The same applies to B22, B42, B12.

sections.heading: 3. RELATED WORKS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Sequence classification
sections.text: Existing sequence classification methods can be divided into three broad categories [19]: (1) feature-based classification, (2) sequence distance-based classification, and (3) model-based classification. In feature-based classification, a sequence is transformed into a feature vector. This representation scheme could lead to very high-dimensional feature spaces. The feature extraction step is very important as it affects the classification results.This step should deal with many parameters, such as criteria for selecting features (e.g. frequency and length) and the type of linkages (i.e. accurate or inaccurate with gaps).After adapting the input data format, a conventional classification methodology is appliced.In sequence-based classification, a distance function should be defined to determine the similarity between a pair of characteristics (e.g. frequency and length) of the sequence method and inaccuracy of the next (i.e., relative to the neighbor).

sections.heading: 4. MIL-BASED APPROACHES FOR SEQUENCE DATA
sections.text: In this section we present the proposed approaches to MIL in sequence data and the naive approach to solving the problem of MIL in sequence data.

sections.heading: 4.1 Naive approach for MIL in sequence data
sections.text: The easiest way to solve the problem of MIL for sequence data is to use standard MIL classification systems. However, most common MIL algorithms require a uniform attribute format that encompasses all types of terms; the second stage is to apply an existing MIL classification system; the first stage is an approach that implements a number of attributes in the sequencer matrix; the second stage is to apply an existing MIL classification system; and the second stage illustrates MIL's naive approach to the sequencer matrix. In the case of sequence data that is most commonly used to transform data, the attribute is to be extracted; and the second stage is to apply an existing MIL classification system.

sections.heading: 5. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: We apply the proposed approaches to the problem of phenotype prediction of bacterial ionizing radiation resistance (IRR), which can be formulated as a MIL problem for sequence data [3]. Bacteria represent the bags and the primary structure of basal DNA repair proteins. In this context, an unknown bacterium is associated with either Ionizing Radiation Resistant Bacteria (IRRB) or Ionizing Radiation Sensitive Bacteria (IRSB). For our tests, we used the data set described in [3]. This data set consists of 28 bags (14 IRRB and 14 IRSB). Each bacterium / bag contains 25 to 31 cases corresponding to proteins involved in basal DNA repair in IRRB [3]. For more detailed information about our data sets and our experiments in general, please see the following link: http: / / fccc.maisi.fr / MIdhi / L.

sections.heading: 5.1 Experimental environment
sections.text: The calculations were performed on an i7 2.49 GHz CPU PC with 6 GB of RAM under Linux Ubuntu. We used the WEKA data mining tool [8] to apply existing multiple instance classifiers using the naïve approach. To deal with the ABSim approach, we used a local alignment technique as a benchmark. In our tests, the basic local alignment search tool (BLAST) [1] was used to calculate local alignments.

sections.heading: 5.2 Experimental protocol
sections.text: In our context, the Leave-One-Out (LOO) technique is considered the most objective test method compared to other techniques such as hold-out and cross-validation, which can be explained by the fact that our training set contains a small number of bags. For each data set (consisting of n bags), only one bag is retained for the test and the remaining bags are used for training. To evaluate the naive approach and approach to bag classification, we first encode the protein sequences of each bag using a set of features / motifs generated by an existing motion extraction method. We then apply an existing classifier to the coded data. In our tests, we used DMS [12] as a motivation extraction method. DMS allows the construction of motifs that can distinguish one family of proteins from another. It first identifies motifs in the protein sequences.

sections.heading: 5.3 Experimental results
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: We have described two new approaches to MIL in sequence data: (1) ABClass and (2) ABSim. We have applied the proposed approaches to the problem of predicting ionizing radiation resistance (IRR) in bacteria. By conducting experiments, we have shown that the proposed approaches are efficient. We are able to successfully predict the IRR of most bacteria, but do not achieve 100% accuracy when using the different experimental settings with all proteins. In future work, we will explore how the use of A-priori knowledge can improve the efficiency of our algorithm.

In [22], HyDR-MI (which stands for hybrid dimensionality reduction method for multiple instance learning) is proposed as a feature subset selection method for MIL algorithms.

The hybrid consists of the filter component based on an extension of the ReliefF algorithm [21] developed to work with MIL and the wrapper component based on a genetic algorithm that optimizes the search for the best feature subset from a reduced set of features, output by the filter component.

metadata.abstractText: In Multiple Instance Learning (MIL) problem for sequence data, the learning data consist of a set of bags where each bag contains a set of instances/sequences. In many real world applications such as bioinformatics, web mining, and text mining, comparing a random couple of sequences makes no sense. In fact, each instance of each bag may have structural and/or temporal relation with other instances in other bags. Thus, the classification task should take into account the relation between semantically related instances across bags. In this paper, we present two novel MIL approaches for sequence data classification: (1) ABClass and (2) ABSim. In ABClass, each sequence is represented by one vector of attributes. For each sequence of the unknown bag, a discriminative classifier is applied in order to compute a partial classification result. Then, an aggregation method is applied to these partial results in order to generate the final result. In ABSim, we use a similarity measure between each sequence of the unknown bag and the corresponding sequences in the learning bags. An unknown bag is labeled with the bag that presents more similar sequences. We applied both approaches to the problem of bacterial Ionizing Radiation Resistance (IRR) prediction. We evaluated and discussed the proposed approaches on well known Ionizing Radiation Resistance Bacteria (IRRB) and Ionizing Radiation Sensitive Bacteria (IRSB) represented by primary structure of basal DNA repair proteins. The experimental results show that both ABClass and ABSim approaches are efficient.
